Dear Jim and all

When I first looked I thought it was a tosho (tsuba made by a sword 
smith), it also
had the field of a tempo with out the stamps (do tempo have to have stamps?)
Also had the look of some Myochin in the carving so the surface work seem
to be no as refine as an example of Kiyofusa (Myochin) in Japanese sword 
guard Artists by Murtha

But more like Nobuiye as found in a sales catalog I have from 1982 and 
in Haynes #7 catalog #37 there
is another Nobuiye that has the same feel.  I also saw some Saotome that 
also look close.

So I think that it is a Saotome in the style of Nobuiye. 

       Can I do that?? 

Now why does it have such a large hitsuana.

Now I will go read the other quesses

later
david
